LRC : ARABLE LRC LANDS IN MONARAGALA DISTRICT:
PROVISION OF TITLE DEEDS TO OCCUPANTS 722/2025 1. ...
asked the Minister of Agriculture, Livestock, Land and Irrigation:
(i) the extent of the arable government lands in the Monaragala District;
(ii) the extent of the lands owned by the Land Reform Commission in the Monaragala District;
(iii) whether he is aware that the issuance of deeds for the lands concerned has been suspended at present;

(iv) whether he is aware that title deeds/land permits have not yet been issued to persons who have been possessing the lands belonging to the Land Reform Commission for long periods of about 25 to 30 years; and
(v) whether steps will be taken to issue title deeds/ land permits to the persons concerned?
() ( ) ( () - ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Susil Ranasinghe - Deputy Minister of Land and Irrigation) 8
() ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Susil Ranasinghe) LRC 8 8 8 8 8 13 8 8 LRC 8 LRC 8 8 8
: PROJECTS APPROVED TO BE IMPLEMENTED WITH ASSISTANCE OF INDIAN GOVERNMENT: EASTERN PROVINCE
asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Education, Higher Education and Vocational Education:
(i) the details of all approved projects to be

implemented in the Eastern Province of Sri Lanka under the assistance of the Government of India, pursuant to the Memorandum of Understanding signed between the President of Sri Lanka and the Prime Minister of India during Indian Prime Ministers visit to Sri Lanka;
(ii) the process followed in identifying and
approving each of the above projects, separately;
(iii) whether relevant stakeholders were consulted during the process of identifying the aforesaid projects; and
(iv) if so, the names and other relevant details

. ( . ) (The Hon. M. Nizam Kariapper, PC) Thank you. Actually my second Supplementary Question is a continuation of what I asked first. Madam Prime Minister, I want to know about the opportunity that the Members of Parliament representing the East had in that. - 8
E.L. IRFAN AND K.S. NISHFAR: COMPENSATION FOR BOAT
asked the Minister of Fisheries, Aquatic and Ocean Resources:

(a) Is he aware that - (i) a fisherman named E.L. Irfan, a resident of Sinna Palamunai area, who had ventured for deep sea fishing from the Kappaladi fishing pier in Addalachchenai on 12.07.2024 was washed ashore on Tamil Nadu coast and was brought back to Sri Lanka on 20.11.2024 after 130 days; and (ii) a fisherman named K.S. Nishfar, a resident of Addalachchenai 06 area died during the incident?

(b) Will he inform this House - (i) whether the Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources has paid compensation to the deceased fisherman K.S. Nishfar; (ii) whether compensation has been paid to fisherman E.L. Irfan and for his damaged boat; and (iii) if so, the amounts paid as compensation to the above-mentioned fishermen, separately?
(c) If not, why? ( ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Ramalingam Chandrasekar - Minister of Fisheries, Aquatic and Ocean Resources) , :
REGULATION OF FERTILIZER ACT: MAXIMUM PENALTY ON
() , ? asked the Minister of Agriculture, Livestock, Land and Irrigation:
(i) the year in which the Regulation of Fertilizer Act was presented to the Parliament of Sri Lanka;
(ii) the maximum penalty that can be imposed on a fake fertilizer manufacturer under that Act;
(iii) whether the standard of the fertilizers available in the market is examined; and
(iv) whether there is any course of action in Sri Lanka to produce organic and chemical fertilizers or to encourage such production?
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Namal Karunaratne - Deputy Minister of Agriculture and Livestock) 8
asked the Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs:
(i) whether he is aware that there is a land issue in Humbuluwa village in Alawwa in Dambadeniya;
(ii) whether the Humbuluwa Village Plan No. 455 prepared according to the survey of the year 1911 is in force;
(iii) whether he is aware that the lands belonging to the above village since the year 1910 have been mentioned by the Department of Land Title Settlement as private hereditary lands;
(iv) whether the grant bearing No. 2621 has been registered;
(v) if so, the date on which the said grant was registered and the relevant area of land, separately;
(vi) the date on which Humbuluwa Temple came under Section 4(1) of the Buddhist Temporalities (Amendment) Act, No. 34 of 2013;
(vii) the reasons for the depriving of the right to claim the freehold lands traditionally possessed by the people of Humbuluwa village after the year 2017;
(viii) the reasons for not informing the villagers in that regard;
(ix) whether he accepts that the peoples sovereignty, as provided in the Constitution of Sri Lanka, has been violated due to this; and
(x) the measures that will be taken regarding the above-mentioned issue?
() ( ) ( () - , ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Hiniduma Sunil Senevi - Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs) 8

POSTS OF SENIOR LECTURER AND SENIOR EDUCATOR OF
asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Education, Higher Education and Vocational Education:

(a) Will she inform this House - (i) whether the qualification of having obtained a bachelor's degree with a class, which was a requirement for recruitment to the posts of Senior Lecturer and Senior Educator of the National Institute of Education, has been removed in the process of updating the said recruitment scheme; (ii) similarly, whether the previous requirement of having the qualification of experience in teaching has also been removed; (iii) whether the previous requirement of having the qualification of experience obtained from a recognized institution has been amended to include experience obtained from a recognized private institution in the process of updating the recruitment scheme for the above-mentioned posts; and (iv) the objectives of amending the recruitment qualifications as is mentioned above? (b) If not, why ?
() ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Harini Amarasuriya) - Class - 8 Class 8 8 Class 8 condition 8 8 8 8 8 8 8 8 8 8 8
STATE LANDS GRANTED TO PRIVATE PLANTATION
asked the Minister of Plantation and Community Infrastructure:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) the extent of land granted to private plantation companies, out of the State-owned lands in the Matara District; (ii) the name of each of the companies to which such lands were made available, the extent of lands given to each such company and the crops grown on each of the lands, separately; (iii) the extent of land in which cultivation has been carried out, out of the lands given to the plantation companies referred to above; (iv) the names of the plantation companies which have not carried out cultivation activities on the lands given to them, out of the plantation companies referred to above; (v) whether plans have been made to take those lands back to the Government; and (vi) whether revenues accruable to the Government have been recovered properly from the plantation companies concerned?
() , ? asked the Minister of Health and Mass Media:
(a) Will he state, separately - (i) the number of specialist doctors services available in Sri Lanka, the names of those services and the number of specialist doctors in each of such services;

(ii) the number of secondary, tertiary and specialized-care hospitals according to the 2020 classification, in which specialist doctors services are not available due to the shortage of specialist doctors and the number of such vacancies prevailing in them;
(iii) the number of those who retired, vacated, obtained overseas leave, died and resigned from each category of the specialist doctors services from 2020 to 2024;
(iv) the number of those who were selected for each specialist doctors service from 2020 to 2024;
(v) if the required number of specialist doctors were selected through a competitive examination based on shortages/ retirements, how many were selected in each of the past five years; and
(vi) the number of specialist doctors over the age of 60 years and in the age band of 55-60?
(i) the number of graded hospitals which should have specialist doctors services;
(ii) if the Post-Graduate Institute and the relevant College do not pass specialist doctors in necessary numbers, the reasons for it; and
(iii) whether steps will be taken to rectify it?
(c) If not, why? () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Nalinda Jayatissa) 8

() , ? asked the Minister of Public Administration, Provincial Councils and Local Government:
(i) whether he is aware that there are graduates among the officers placed in PL 1, PL 2 and PL 3 salary scales according to the Public Administration Circular 06/2006;
(ii) if so, the number of such graduates;
(iii) whether the aforementioned underemployed graduates will be provided with suitable places of work;
(iv) if so, the methodology that will be adopted to implement that;
(v) the solution that will be provided to the graduates over 40 years of age, who are among the underemployed;
(vi) whether there is a system in place to promote underemployed graduates based on their qualifications without conducting an examination; and
(vi) if not, whether such a system will be introduced?

STATEMENT BY MINISTER OF JUSTICE AND
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Harshana Nanayakkara, Attorney-at-Law - Minister of Justice and National Integration) 2025802828 27(2) 8

( ) (The Hon. Harshana Nanayakkara, Attorney-at-Law) As I have indicated to you, Hon. Member, granting of pardon is basically a Presidential prerogative and a right, according to the Constitution. That is why, in my Answer, I said that as per Article 34 of the Constitution, the President has the powers, not the Minister of Justice. However, a group of about 15 persons, whose loved ones are now convicted and imprisoned under the Prevention of Terrorism Act, their families, came to meet me and handed over a letter. So, those names had been taken in and are being considered at the moment as to what we could do. Other than that, I cannot make any promise because this prerogative is not within the purview of the Ministry of Justice, but with the President. So, whatever applications you have, you may present them to the President also. However, the members of their families came and spoke to me. That is a matter I am studying now. There were about 11 or 15 individuals in that letter, if I am not mistaken.
That is my Answer. ( ) (The Hon. Speaker) 27(8) 88 8

( ) (The Hon. Speaker) The Hon. Kathiravelu Shanmugam Kugathasan. You have 16 minutes.
Whereupon THE HON. SPEAKER left the Chair, and DEPUTY SPEAKER [THE HON. (DR.) RIZVIE SALIH] took the Chair.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) The Hon. Chathuranga Abeysinghe. You have 12 minutes.

( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Chathuranga Abeysinghe - Deputy Minister of Industry and Entrepreneurship Development) Hon. Deputy Speaker, I think it is a very important Debate that we have today. After nine months of governance, the new Government is reviewing and explaining to the country how the economy has been moving from stability to growth.

About the economy, the Hon. President clearly articulated and told the Opposition, Tell us a particular indicator that is going in the wrong direction. So, when we talk about the economy, basically it is explained and reviewed through indicators and those indicators are mostly in economic terms. There are also social and environmental indicators, matrices which tell us whether the economy is moving forward in the right direction. But, what we know is, for the last 40 years, all those indicators have been moving away from their targets. So, I need to iterate a little bit to make the experts in front of me understand what kind of a country that we have been making over the last 30 to 40 years, where we have already made 30 per cent of our population poor or to be below the poverty line. Then, on an annual basis, we had a widening trade gap as big as eight billion US Dollars.

That is because of the industrial policies and strategies they conducted and we also had a continuingly increasing fiscal deficit, which led us to a lot of debts and the crisis we have been facing for the last few years. And, we, as a country, have the highest interest cost in the world compared to government revenue and has one of the highest number of people who cannot repay at these interest rates. So, these are the indicators we have been left with over the past few years and we were among the lowest tax collecting nations. The tax collection as a percentage of GDP was 8.5 per cent in 2019 and even now, we use indirect taxes to collect these revenues.
That is the root cause for the issues we faced as a country and the parties responsible for that are in front of us, giving advice to us today.

If you really look at what the Opposition said before the elections, you would see that they claimed or blamed the NPP for several things, especially with regard to the handling of the economy. They went on stage and said that the NPP basically does not have the skill, the experience and the expertise to run the economy. They also said that foreign investors would run away when the NPP comes into power because our flag is red. Then, they thought that there would be another crisis within a few months of the Government coming into power. Some in the Opposition said that within six months, this Government would collapse and the people would come on to the streets. At the same time, the economic experts on the other side said that we have no capability to deal with the IMF and that the IMF programme would collapse. Those are the things that they used to say on stage to convince that the NPP is not capable of handling the economy. Also, they engaged in fearmongering, saying that when the NPP comes in to power, it would take over private assets and would nationalize all the companies in the country. Those are the lies they told. Not only that, after the Government was formed, when we were striving to fix or stabilize the economy, they used various statements to put fear back into the people to destabilize this economy. Now, what we understand is that everything they have been preaching has been proven wrong by this Government.

Sir, if you want to really look at the fundamentals needed for a countrys economic growth, we need to take lessons from countries like Singapore. I was lucky enough to meet Dr. Kishore Mahbubani last week and to share some thoughts. He is famous in the economic sphere and says that the rule of law, meritocracy and discipline are the base for a countrys economic growth. And, what we are trying to showcase is that this Government is following that path and those traits. We really need to ask the Opposition, Have you ever been able to exercise meritocracy? If you really look at their advisers to the Government and the CEOs of the State-owned institutions, were they of that calibre who could run the institutions with no interest in or with no affiliation to politics?
As you can see, the Hon. (Dr.) Anil Jayantha is leading the front as the Deputy Finance Minister and (Dr.) Harshana Suriyapperuma has been doing his part,

both as Deputy Minister of Finance then and now, as the Secretary to the Ministry of Finance. They are examples of meritocracy and you can also see that we, as a Government, have given merit and the credit to the Central Bank Governor and the people who have been handling this process earlier. So, all that was done on merit. We have never had this experience in the history of our country, where the governing party have given people responsibilities on merit.

Very recently, I was fortunate to be part of a research finding forum conducted by Verit Research. At that forum, they explained how Sri Lanka is faring based on the assumptions of the Debt Sustainability Analysis of the IMF. It is very interesting to note that, as a country, we are doing far better than what was predicted for the country, and especially with regard to government revenue, we are doing better than what was expected with this year's revenue collection being 18 per cent more that that of the previous year. And the primary balance is better than what was expected and public debt, as a percentage of GDP, has been coming down continuously and we say we will work to better the predictions for 2029. The only indicator that is moving away from the original forecast is the interest cost, which is a little high. But, if you look at exchange rate stability, the inflation interest rates, the current account surplus and the official reserves, we have beaten the targets that were given to us. So, that is why we keep on asking anyone to tell us an indicator which indicates that Sri Lanka would derail again, that Sri Lanka would fail again. These are the fears you all have in your minds, you all dream in your dreams for this Government to fail and for you all to come to power. That is not going to happen, we would say.

Also, there were certain social indicators that we need to look at like poverty, employment and real wages. Yes, we understand that those have not been improving. They cannot be improved in a year. This is a systematic failure that you all brought about over and over again over the decades. So, it will take some time for these benefits to trickle down to the people, and we are pretty sure that the poverty indicator and the rest of the social indicators will improve over a period of time.

At that same Forum, economist Ms. Subhashini Abeysinghe shared very interesting findings about how small nations in the world could prosper. She took up examples from small nations like Sri Lanka to say that there were two main factors for an economy to thrive. One particular factor which I heard being discussed for the first time in an economic forum is that good governance and hygiene are a must or have to be the base for a country to prosper, and I am happy to say that for the last nine months, we have been putting things in place. We have been bringing in digital technology and have been driving for good governance. moving up in Corruption Perceptions Index, Ease of Doing Business Index and the Innovation Index. Digital penetration of this country will improve, giving us the necessary environment for businesses to come up, investors to come in and to make a level playing field for business to thrive in the Sri Lankan economy.

The second factor she mentioned was, access to market. It was discussed that all these small nations have greater access to markets through bilateral and multilateral agreements. Sometimes, it is funny to hear the Opposition pushing us now for that. But, while they were ruling, they had no ability to balance those or to ensure that we get into trade agreements and that our domestic industries are made strong and competitive to fight with those goods and services on the international market. So, what we are doing now is, parallely, supporting the industry to become efficient and productive so that we could open up our markets and getting into trade agreements, both regionally and globally. I think those two factors will ensure that Sri Lanka moves forward.

Another thing that we need to understand is that though we have moved from crisis to stability, in achieving economic growth, the IMF programme is restrictive in certain ways on Government expenditure. So, with that, we are trying to prioritize our expenditure to support our industries. We are also trying to support the marginalized communities, ensuring that we are within the growth trajectory, which we see from the data that was produced today.

So, what do we have today? We have the Government expenditure, which is the largest consumer or the spending of the economy, close to Rs.4 trillion with Rs.1.3 trillion in Capital Expenditure. That is the biggest investment which has happened during the last few years and which is going to grow the economy at a faster rate than what we are having today. Then, in terms of exports, we have reached an 8.7 per cent increase. So, exports are increasing in a positive way and not in a generic way because market diversification is happening today. Exports to Europe, Africa and East Asia are improving at a higher rate than anybody anticipated, which is over 20 per cent. Then, the manufacturing index of the country is moving at a higher rate, and I am pretty sure that the Ministry of Industries and the Export Development Board are doing the right thing to ensure that we have a growth of more than 9 per cent in manufacturing. If you take private borrowings, they growing at a rate of 16 per cent, which is something that the Opposition never dreamed of. So, those are the results that we are seeing today with the way the NPP economic and the industrial teams managing the economy. And, if you really take bond yields, the long-term and the short-term bond yields are converging, which gives confidence to the investors and shows that this country has secured economic stability because the Government has a two-thirds and is doing the right thing to ensure that the economy thrives.

The next issue is, misinformation about foreign direct investments. We have enough foreign direct investments coming in. We had Inquiries for investments for over US Dollars 4.6 billion and we have already secured US Dollars 536 million of foreign direct investments, which is a growth of about 100 per cent compared to last year. Also, under the Ministry of Industries, we have given approval to start 78 factories, which will be started during this year and in the first half of next year.

So, I am going to wind up saying that the country is moving forward, taking the economy from stability to growth and here, the request for the Opposition is to be part of this journey because Sri Lanka is transforming. Sri Lanka is transforming with reforms to the legal structure, changing the bad political culture and the Government going after the people who wasted public money.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Hon. Chathurange Abeysinghe, your time is up. ( ) (The Hon. Chathuranga Abeysinghe) Sir, please give me ten seconds.

Finally, what we are trying to say is, while the country is moving in the right direction, do not try to pull us back by the leg and make statements which are false and which could create fear among the investors and the business community. We are doing all this in a very honest way, and also, we need the support of the Opposition to take Sri Lanka towards growth since we are on the right trajectory.
Thank you very much. ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Next, the Hon. Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa.

[88 5816] ( ) (The Hon. Mujibur Rahman) 8 8 With great pride as an old Zahirian, I extend my heartfelt wishes to Zahira College and Hameed Al Husseinie College for the Big Match. As an old Zahirian, it is always a proud moment to see our alma mater take to the field, especially in a match like this themed on tradition and brotherhood. This Sunday encounter between two oldest Muslim schools in the country is more than just a game; it is a celebration of history, sportsmanship and unity. I wish both teams the very best! May the match be competitive, respectful and a true showcase of the talent and spirit within our community! All the best for both the teams!
